WRITING.TEXT: My only concern is that Bioware only takes the "its not enough like the OT" complaints to heart and decide to make any future games exactly like ME 1-3 and toss out any of the good things that worked in Andromeda.

I'm not saying that any comparison between the OT and Andromeda aren't valid, but sometimes, people can make the OT out to be this flawless trilogy of games when comparing it to Andromeda, which isn't fair for Andromeda, especially when it comes to things like writing and characters. For example, when people complain that Andromeda doesn't have any likable characters when compared to the OT, they tend to forget how much they disliked Jack or Vega when they were first revealed, or how divisive and disliked Jacob, Ashley, Miranda, and Kaiden were, and to some extent, still are.
Basically, While comparing Andromeda and the OT are fine, I just think calling a spade a spade should go both ways.

I agree that not being as good as the OT doesn't equal Andromeda being a bad game and I wish a lot more people had that mentality. But what I also hope people keep in mind is that the OT had its problems and received some criticism when it came to the complaints of cheesy writing, the characters (remember how everyone reacted when they first saw Jack in ME2 or how the human squamates from 1 and 2 were disliked), and glitches(too many to name in one comment).

WRITING.TITLE: [COD] Should there be a crime based COD?
WRITING.TEXT:
One of the biggest debates going on in the Call of Duty community right now is what setting should future titles take place in. An avenue that I think has potential is for COD do to a crime based game.
Now, when I say crime based, I don't necessarily mean in the same vain as Battlefield:Hardline, but rather a game that deals with the world of illegal drugs and the efforts to combat them. For those that think that the game based on this couldn't work, here are a few reasons I think it would.
1. It's global: When most people think of the WOD, they immediately think of the Central and South American drug cartels, but illegal narcotics is a worldwide trade, with things such as the golden triangle in SouthEast Asia and the Afghan heroin trade, so a COD focusing on this wouldn't lose the globetrotting the series is known for.
2. It covers decades: A game based on the War on Drugs would have decades of information for the devs to work with, and could cover any and everything from the efforts to combat the growing drug cartels in South America and the Heroin and Crack epidemics in America in the 80's to counter drug operations being done today in places like Afghanistan by Federal Law Enforcement agencies (http://abcnews.go.com/International/dea-heroin-haul-largest-afghanistan-world/story?id=44216333, http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/334691)
3. Its different: Like I stated above, figuring out where the COD should go next has been a source of debate for a lot of fans. This idea would allow the franchise to explore territory it hasn't been to yet

WRITING.TITLE: [No Spoilers] A rework of Jacob
WRITING.TEXT:
As most us know and agree with, Jacob is probably one of the, if not the least interesting squamates in the ME trilogy. But I think that the character has some potential, so I decided to rework his backstory in an attempt to make it at least a bit more interesting, so here it goes.
The first thing I would change about Jacob is that instead of being a nondescript Alliance Marine and "Corsair", I would make him a dishonorably discharged N7 officer. What led to his discharge was the mission he and Miranda undertook to stop a Batarian bio-weapon on the Citadel (which he mentions in your dialog with him, in case you forgot). In order to accomplish this mission, however, Jacob had to destroy a transport carrying the weapon, but also had several civilians on board. When questioned about the decision he made by the Alliance, Jacobs gives a response that basically equates to the ends justifying the means. This doesn't fly with the brass and Jacob loses his N7 designation and is drummed out of the Alliance. Jacob's actions, however, caught the attention of the Illusive Man, who offers Jacob a job as an operative. And while Jacob stands by his decision to his destroy the transport, deep down, he feels guilty about the lives he took. This guilt would better explain why decided to defend the defecting Cerberus Scientists in ME3 as a form of redemption rather than the 'I meditated and decided to do this' line we were given.
